heading: storage system glows brightly
subheading: an israeli company has invented a way to put multiple layers of data on a cd, storing up to 150 gb. it has also come up with a pc card that can store up to 10 gb. tania hershman reports from jerusalem.
author: tania hershman
text: jerusalem -- tomorrow's computer storage devices are not just going to shine in terms of performance, they are going to be positively fluorescent. c3d has unveiled its three-dimensional optical memory storage devices, which utilize fluorescent chemicals to pack gigabytes and even terrabytes into every square centimeter of disk space.it is c3d's fluorescent multi-layer (fm) technology which enables the regular-sized 120mm fmd-rom disk to store 140 gb, compared to today's 650 megabyte cd-rom disks and 5 gb dvds.with its 10 gb capacity, the credit-card sized fmc clearcard smartcard stores 2,500 times more data than the current 4 mb smartcards. while this leap in storage capacity was made possible by c3d's novel usage of fluorescent chemicals, the company was not alone in exploring this avenue."we are not the only ones who thought fluorescence might be good for optical memory," explains dr alexander libin, the director of c3d's israel facility. "fluorescence has been known for 200 years."however, the fluorescent materials that had been identified were too chemically unstable to be used in any kind of technological device. but 4-year-old c3d, whose 65 employees are distributed between facilities in israel, the united states, russia, and ukraine, didn't abandon the concept.the company instead developed its own range of fluorescent chemicals, which are stable enough to meet the requirements of today's technology. the resulting processes and technologies are now the subject of 70 patent applications.while there are competitors investigating fluorescent optical storage, c3d is the first to demonstrate fully working devices. in contrast to current two-dimensional optical storage devices, which are based on reflection of light from the pits and grooves etched on the cd-rom, c3d's devices are based on three-dimensional fluorescence of chemicals in the pits and grooves.the technology exploits the unique property of fluorescent chemicals to produce both "coherent" light and "incoherent" light when stimulated by laser light. in coherent light (of which laser light is an example), all the light waves are in step, but in incoherent light, they are out of step.this incoherence allows for multi-layering, which means that a device can have hundreds of layers of stored data that can be read simultaneously. the fmd-rom demonstrated this week had six layers and the clearcard 10 layers, but "at the moment we are working on 20 layers, and we don't see a limit to the number of layers," libin said.because more than one layer can be read at a time, information retrieval is fast. higher storage capacity and retrieval speeds do not necessarily mean higher prices. c3d claims that the cost of fluorescent multi-layer devices will be "at least an order of magnitude less" than current optical and magnetic storage.size is also not an issue for the technology, which could be used in everything from credit-card sized smartcards to mobile telephones, pdas, and televisions. however, the devices shown this week are just prototypes.the technology will not be on the market for at least a year as the company works on card and disk drives, which will be backwards-compatible to read existing disks. c3d is also working on increasing storage capacity to terrabytes (1,000 gb) and producing disks that can be written on many times as well as rom (read-only) and wrom (write-once-read-many) disks.c3d is currently searching for suitable strategic partners to take it up to the next level, "first and foremost in japan," says libin, although the technology will be demonstrated in silicon valley in november. responses have been very positive so far, says ceo eugene levich, a native of russia who came to israel in the mid-1970s.some press reports have been calling the technology "revolutionary." "i don't like 'revolutionary,'" levich says. "i am a cautious man. i use [it] reluctantly, even though i think it's true. the facts are on the ground."
